source.title: Cloning the guide RNA into pSpCas9(BB)-2A-GFP (pX458) – Digestion of the vector with BbsI

source.description:
Digest
of pX458 with BbsI
at
BbsI reaction mix:
NEB buffer 2.1 5.0 µl
BbsI enzyme 1.0 µl
100X BSA 0.5 µl
pX458 plasmid 3.0 µg
Water to 50 µl

source.body: The overnight digestion with BbsI significantly reduces negative colonies.

source.title: Gel purification of the digested plasmid

source.description:
Add
loading dye to the mixture and load onto
agarose gel. Use the same amount of the undigested pX458 vector as a negative control.

source.title: Gel purification of the digested plasmid

source.description: Use a transilluminator to excise the digested band using a clean scalpel and use the QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen, 28704) to isolate the digested plasmid.

source.body: The use of the blue light dark reader transilluminator (Clare Chemical Research, USA) may reduce DNA damage during gel excision. The digested plasmid runs between supercoiled and relaxed DNA in the undigested control sample.

source.description:

of gel equivalent to

of QG buffer for
of gel.

source.body: The method described here is adapted from the kit manual with minor changes (QIAquick gel extraction kit, Qiagen, 28704).

source.body: The addition of sodium acetate significantly increases the final yield of the DNA.

source.description: Add one gel-volume of isopropanol and vortex briefly.

Transfer the mixture into the QIAquick column and centrifuge at

source.body: If there is more dissolved gel mixture left, add to the same column and repeat step 7.

source.body: Centrifuging at 9000 x g reduces the chance of breaking off the Eppendorf tube’s lid.

source.title: Ligation of guide sequence into pX458 plasmid

source.description:

Reverse (100 µM) 1 µl

Water 6 µl

of nuclease-free water. We use one microliter of this

annealed sgRNA 1 µl
T4 ligase Buffer 1 µl

Water to 10 µl

source.body: Typically, we incubate 2 hours at room temperature and start the transformation. Keep the rest of the ligation mix at 16oC overnight. If the first transformation does not result in colonies, then retransform the ligated product the next day.

source.title: Testing sgRNA using surveyor assay –  Transfection of the sgRNA construct

source.description: Plate 30% confluent HEK293T cells in 6 well plate (start with 2 x 105 cells).

of sgRNA plasmid with lipofectamine 3000 reagents as described in steps 5 – 9 from

source.title: Testing sgRNA using surveyor assay –  Transfection of the sgRNA construct

source.description:
Twenty-four hours after transfection, replace media with
new media.

source.body: GFP in the pX458 plasmid allows easy assessment of the transfection efficiency. Observe the transfected cells under a fluorescent microscope using a green filter. Higher transfection rates make it easier to assess the efficacy of the sgRNA using surveyor assay

source.title: Testing sgRNA using surveyor assay –  Transfection of the sgRNA construct

source.description:
Seventy-two hours after transfection, remove
of media and collect the cells in the remaining
of media by pipetting up and down and transfer into a 1.5 ml tube.

source.title: Testing sgRNA using surveyor assay –  Transfection of the sgRNA construct

source.description:
Centrifuge cells at
for
using a fixed angle rotor table top centrifuge and remove media. Cells can be stored at
or directly begin genomic DNA isolation.

source.title: Testing sgRNA using surveyor assay –  Transfection of the sgRNA construct

source.description:
Proceed with genomic DNA isolation, as described in steps 25 – 35 from
basic protocol 1
.
Make a PCR master mix by adding all the components except genomic DNA and gene specific primers adjusted for the total number of reactions.

source.body:
To amplify the region targeted by the sgRNA, design a set of forward and reverse primers. The forward primer should be ~250 bp upstream from the sgRNA cutting site and the reverse primer should be ~250 bp downstream. To facilitate mutation detection, we recommend an amplicon size of 500bp to 1Kb with an sgRNA cut site close to the center of the amplicon. There are several tools to pick appropriate primer sets, such as from Primer3, IDT or Benchling (Untergasser et al., 2012; Benchling, 2019) https://www.idtdna.com/pages/tools/primerquest). The double stranded DNA breaks generated by CRISPR-Cas9 are typically repaired by error prone non-homologous repair, which results in several types of mutations. The mutated PCR products, when annealed with the wild type or other mutated PCR products, generate a mismatch proximal to the cut site. The surveyor enzymes recognize this mismatch and cleave the heteroduplex at the site of mismatch (Figure 6). The assay produces three fragments, one undigested and two digested fragments. Depending on the site of mismatch, the digested fragments run either as one or two bands (Figure 6B&C). If the sgRNA cutting site is at the center of the PCR product, it generates two unresolvable fragments, whereas unequal fragments run as distinct bands. There is no need to mix wild type PCR products with the PCR products of the sgRNA transfected cells for the assay because many different repair products will form and other sites in the population will remain unmodified. One set of primers is required for each terminus of the gene to test sgRNAs that target these sites.
We used Platinum Taq DNA polymerase or Platinum Taq DNA Polymerase High Fidelity for genomic PCR. For each primer set, it is necessary to determine the annealing temperature empirically. We find that an annealing temperature within 3 degrees of the lowest melting temperature (Tm) works well. Additionally, adding denaturants such as DMSO or Betaine may help to amplify GC rich genomic regions.

source.description:
Aliquot
of the master mix into 0.2 ml PCR tubes and add
of
genomic DNA into each reaction mix. The parental HEK293T DNA serves as a negative control.

Add
each of forward and reverse primers of the corresponding gene targeted.

PCR mix:
Genomic DNA 5.0 µl
Gene Primer F 1.0 µl
Gene Primer R 1.0 µl
10X HF buffer 2.5 µl
DMSO (100%) 0.5 µl
10 mM DNTP 1.0 µl
MgSO4 1.0 µl
Platinum Taq DNA Polymerase High Fidelity 0.5 µl
Water 12.5 µl
Run PCR as follows:
Initial denaturation
30 cycles of
___°C.
(Annealing temperature changes based on the primers used)
Final extension
hold ∞

source.body: Annealing and extension of the PCR steps depends on the primers and Taq DNA polymerase used.

source.description:
Check PCR amplification by running
of the products on an agarose gel. Add
6x DNA sample buffer to
of PCR product and load onto a
agarose gel.

source.body: Keep the remainder of the PCR product for the surveyor assay. This step makes sure the PCR worked before starting the surveyor assay.

source.description:
Run the samples at constant 90V and visualize the bands using a UV transilluminator (follow steps 38 – 42 from
basic protocol 1
). If there is only one bright PCR product, proceed with the surveyor assay.

Denature the PCR products from
at
for
and then allow to renature stepwise using the following program:
hold ∞
A ramp down rate of
/sec is recommended.

source.body: This step involves denaturation followed by annealing of the PCR products to form heteroduplexes, followed by a surveyor nuclease reaction. The denaturation and renaturation step is essential because the final cycle of PCR generates homoduplexes that are not recognized by the surveyor nuclease.

source.description:
Surveyor nuclease reaction mix:
Reannealed PCR product 20.0 µl
Surveyor Nuclease S 1.0 µl
Surveyor Enhancer S 1.0 µl
0.15 M MgCl2 Solution 2.0 µl

Mix by pipetting and incubate at
for
in a thermocycler.

Stop the reaction by adding
of Stop Solution and mix.

source.body: Either directly electrophoresis the sample on a 2% agarose gel after mixing with loading dye or store at -20°C for future use.

source.description: Run the samples at constant 90V and visualize the bands using a UV transilluminator. Follow steps 38 – 42 from basic protocol 1 for running and visualizing the samples. The ratio of the undigested band with that of the digested band gives an estimate of relative sgRNA efficiency.

source.body: As an example, we designed two sgRNA that target the 3' end of FOXM1 coding regions (Figure 6B&C).

source.title: PCR amplification of Homology Directed Repair construct

source.description: Synthesize the designed primers from Integrated DNA Technologies (IDT), adding phosphorothioate as a modification to the primer in the details.

source.title: PCR amplification of Homology Directed Repair construct

source.description:
Amplify the HDR template using the primers and Platinum Taq DNA Polymerase High Fidelity. We perform several 50 µl reactions (typically 4 to 8), and gel purify the PCR products.
PCR mix:
Plasmid DNA 50.0 ng
10 µM Primer F 1.0 µl
10 µM Primer R 1.0 µl
10XHigh Fidelity buffer 5.0 µl
DMSO 0.5 µl
10 mM DNTP 2.0 µl
MgSO4 2.0 µl
Platinum Taq DNA Polymerase High Fidelity 0.5 µl
Water to 50 µl
Use PCR condition as follows:
Initial denaturation
30 cycles of
Final extension
hold ∞

source.body: Removing any remaining primer from the PCR products is important as primers may interfere with homologous recombination. The primers are very long, so conventional PCR clean-up kits will not remove primers efficiently and reduce the HDR efficiency by binding to the cut site. Always gel purify the PCR products.

source.description: Run the PCR products on an agarose gel and cut out the repair construct band.
Combine all the gel slices into one tube and purify the DNA using the Qiagen gel purification kit similar to steps 2 – 12.

Elute DNA using
to
nuclease-free water and quantify using a NanoDrop and store at
. DNA is stable in
for several months.
Grow the ARF-AID progenitor cells and split into six-well plates to ~30% confluency.

Cotransfect
of gene-specific sgRNA plasmid and
of double-stranded homology repair template PCR product to the cells as described in steps 1 – 9 of
basic protocol 1
. Use
–
Lipofectamine reagent for transfection. The parental pX458 cotransfected with HDR PCR product is used as a transfection control and we recommend keeping a untransfected control cell well.

source.body: Transfect multiple (at least 4 wells) wells to get enough colonies.

source.description: Replace with new media 24 hours after transfection.
After forty-eight hours, expand each well into a 10 cm plate.

source.body: Expanding cells into 10 cm plates spreads cells so they form isolated colonies.

source.description:
Seventy-two hours after transfection, add
final concentration of hygromycin B to the cells and keep in the selection media until all cells in the untransfected control condition die. Antibiotic selection concentration varies between cell types. We recommend plotting a titration vs. cell viability curve to determine the lowest concentration at which nearly all cells die within 7 – 12 days.

source.body: If the cell number is low after 72 hours, start hygromycin B selection on the 5th day of transfection. This increases the chance of getting positive colonies. The addition of conditioned media (8:2 ratio of new media with filtered cultured media from the same type of cell) increases the survival of the clones.

source.description: After all the cells in the control plate are dead, replace the media with regular conditioned media in all the transfected cells and control plates.
Colonies will appear in the plates after two or three weeks.
Pick colonies similar to the steps 15 – 22 (from basic protocol 1) and screen for tagged clones by Western blotting.

source.body: We use gene specific antibodies for detecting tagged proteins. The successful tagging results in an increase in protein size of 24 KD. Heterozygous integration will contain bands reflecting both the native and tagged proteins. The non-homologous end repair may produce read through into the 3' UTR or introduce stop codons before normal stop codon of the gene. This is observed as an unexpected size shift that is not ~24KDa. Confirm the integration and reading frame of the integrated AIDP2A-HygR or HygR-P2A-AID by PCR and sequencing.

source.description:
Select colonies from the Western blotting experiment and perform genomic DNA PCR using the same set of primers used for testing sgRNA efficiency according to steps 31 – 34, with the following change: PCR extension time should be increased to
to amplify the insert.

Electrophorese whole PCR product on
agarose gel, excise the band using a clean scalpel and use the Qiagen gel purification kit to isolate genomic DNA (follow steps 2 – 12). Sequence the purified PCR product with the forward primer to confirm the reading frame.

source.body: Successful integration of the AID-P2A-HygR or HygR-P2A-AID results in an addition of approximately 1785 bp to the PCR product. Heterozygous clones will have two bands, one with a length of genomic region between forward and reverse primer and the second with a length of genomic region between primers plus the 1785 bp. The homozygous integration will result in one band with a length of genomic region between primers plus the 1785 bp. Sequence the integrated DNA using the same forward primer, which will confirm successful integration.

description: The next step in developing the ARF-AID system is to tag the gene of interest with AID. The ARF-AID system requires full-length AID (Figure 1) because the characterized interaction domains of AID with ARF are domains III and IV. Domains I and II are involved in the interaction with TIR1. The mini-AID lacks domains III and IV and will not interact with ARF to stabilize the protein in the absence of auxin (Sathyan et al., 2019). Note that the antibiotic selection marker (HygroR) is co-transcribed with AID and the protein products are separated during translation. Therefore, the resistance marker will be expressed at levels comparable to the target protein.
